thread.title: Initiatives boost large-format retailers

author: Philippa Kelly
title: Initiatives boost large-format retailers
text:
Officeworks is one of the many large-format retail sector stores that will benefit from the 2015 federal budget.
The large-format retail sector, consisting of Australia's "big box" retailers, such as The Good Guys, Officeworks, Bunnings, Masters, Beacon Lighting, JB Hi-Fi and Harvey Norman, among others, will be one of the main sectors to benefit from the flow-on effect of the budget's small business package.
In 2009, the sector benefited from a considerable spike in the sale of large flat-screen TVs, as a result of the $950 one-off bonus component of the economic stimulus package provided by the Rudd government.
There are numerous municipalities in the Sydney metropolitan area that do not even have land zoned for large-format retail purposes.
Fast-forward to 2015, and we now have some serious stimulus economic initiatives totalling $5.5 billion included in this year's federal budget that are not just one-off injections into the economy, but rather a far more sustained and targeted package.
The ability for small businesses to claim a tax deduction on assets purchased up to $20,000, either once or on multiple occasions from the night of the budget until June 30, 2017, is clearly the centrepiece of the initiatives.
Advertisement What has been the impact of the budget on the large-format retail sector so far? The real answer is that, while there is a clear and significant boost in business confidence, it is too early to quantify.
Sales in the sector have been generally showing moderate growth, and better than many other sectors of the retail market.
Large-format retailers have just finished a solid end-of-financial year sale time thanks to the budget, record low interest rates and reduced petrol prices.
In NSW, however, benefits of the tax package may be hampered due to the lack of large-format retail stores in NSW. A recently released evidence-based report backed by Professor Allan Fels AO, Large Format Retail in NSW, 'Investment + Competition = Jobs identifies a substantial lack of floor space allocated to the sector; in fact, there are numerous municipalities in the Sydney metropolitan area that do not even have land zoned for large-format retail purposes. There is an increased drive-time for customers to visit a large-format retail outlet in NSW, compared with Victoria and Queensland.
The sector has evolved in Australia as a direct result of consumer demand and occupies around 30 per cent of all retail floor space in Australia; accounting for $59.8 billion a year, or 21.9 per cent of all retail sales. It employs more than 388,000 Australians, both directly and indirectly.
The sector offers a depth of product ranges and is well equipped to meet many of the needs of Australia's small business needs, but in NSW, it desperately needs the planning and zoning laws changed to allow opportunities such as the small business package in the federal budget to be optimised.
Philippa Kelly is the chief executive of the Large Format Retail Association.
